STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
January 7, 2025
Barbara LaRue
GRAND TRAVERSE/LEELANAU/KALKASKA DHHS
701 S ELMWOOD AVE STE 19, Suite 19
TRAVERSE CITY, MI, 49684-3185
Re: License #: CP280201153
Dear Ms. LaRue:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
12/20/2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Samantha Way, Area Manager, at 517-243-9743
Sincerely,
Doug Turrill, Licensing Consultant
701 S. Elmwood
Traverse City, MI 49684
231-383-5531
enclosure

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12205 Required staff
• (8) An agency shall employ or contract for a
sufficient number of competent staff to carry out
the provisions covered by these rules. The
workload for each staff member may not be more
than any of the following:
• (b) Fifteen children assigned to a social
services worker for purposes of providing
direct services in foster care, independent
living, adoption, or post adoption services
or a combination thereof.
The caseloads of two foster care workers exceeded the limit of 15 cases.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement
• (3) The agency shall document all the following in
the child's record before a change of placement
occurs:
• (a) Reason for the change in placement.
One of six files reviewed did not document the reason for a change of placement.
2

CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement
• (3) The agency shall document all the following in
the child’s record before a change of placement
occurs:
• € Replacement preparation of all relevant
parties, including the child or infant, which
includes an explanation as to why the
change is necessary.
One of six files reviewed did not document replacement preparation for all relevant
parties.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement
• (3) The agency shall document all the following in
the child’s record before a change of placement
occurs:
• (f) Notification to the parents, referral
source, lawyer guardian ad litem, and
courts when applicable, of the change in
placement.
One of six files reviewed did not document notification to parents, lawyer guardian
ad litem, and the court.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement
• (3) The agency shall document all the following in
the child’s record before a change of placement
occurs:
• (g) Information about the child was shared
with the new placement, consistent with the
requirements of R 400.12417.
One of six files reviewed did not document that information about the child was
shared with the new placement.
PA 116 722.120 722.120 Investigation, inspection, and examination of
conditions, books, records, and
reports; access by department, bureau of fire
services, or local authorities; records; report;
3

forms; confidentiality; disclosure of information;
availability of confidential records; child
information cards to be provided to department;
failure of licensee to cooperate with
i nvestigation, inspection, or examination
c) Providing accurate and truthful information to the
department, and encouraging witnesses,
such as staff and household members, to provide
accurate and truthful information to the
department.
One of six files reviewed contained a PATP where the foster care worker signed the
signature of the foster parent on the treatment plan.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Uploading Documents: Technical assistance was provided regarding the timely
uploading of documents. There were several incidents of documents that were
not uploaded and the consultant needed to request the documents which were
completed but not uploaded. The agency was informed that documents need to
be uploaded timely and ready for audit reviews.
• Audit Review Changes. The agency was informed that as of October 1, 2024,
DCWL will no longer be auditing compliance with policy. Specifically, FTM's,
medical passport, safety assessments during in home visits, and the thirty day
time frame for PATP signatures will no longer come under the review of DCWL.
• Rule 400.12209 (2) (a) Orientation and Training. The agency was informed that
all the training requirements listed under (2) (a) are required yearly for foster care
workers carrying a caseload as well as for supervisors who may be carrying a
caseload.
• Rule 400.12415 (a) Incident reports. Discussed the requirement that incidents
reports are to be submitted to the consultant. Only those incidents named under
the rule are to be submitted
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Consultation was not requested or provided at this time.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
4

Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency submitted an approved corrective action plan on 11/13/23 in response
to those rule violations established during the renewal inspection completed on
11/09/23. Rule violations established are as follows: R 400.12418 Development of
service plans, Policy FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings. The current Interim
inspection did not establish repeat violations thus indicating that the agency CAP
was successful in preventing repeat violations. It should be noted that FOM 722-
06B FTM was not reviewed during the current inspection as DCWL is longer
reviewing policy compliance during inspections.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrators Annual Assessment was submitted and reviewed. The
assessment thoroughly addressed rule violations established in the 2023 renewal
inspection and the agencies efforts to comply with the CAP.
The assessment addressed the under staffing of the agency that has occurred
over the past several years creating additional burdens on the team. The
assessment also reported a lack of foster homes for placement in addition to the
difficulty of placing children with significant mental health and behavioral needs.
Financial Overview
The agency is a local DHHS office and financial records were not available.
Staff Interviews
Staff interviewed reported enjoying working for the agency. They reported that
their respective supervisors are supportive, and the foster care team works
together. Staff did report that unfilled foster care worker vacancies has placed a
burden on current staff, with caseloads over limit at times.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency is located in a modern local DHHS building in Traverse City. There is
sufficient office space and resources for staff. CHRI documents were observed to
be secured appropriately.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The CPA Analyst generated 4 safety alerts during her visits to the homes. They are as
follows.
Safety Alert #1. The safety alert was generated on 10/25/24. A smoke alarm was
missing between the master bedroom and the rest of the home on the main floor. A
smoke alarm was also missing between the basement bedroom and the rest of the
basement.
5

The alert also noted that a child in the home was not attending school on a regular
basis.
Resolution: Resolution occurred on 11/1/24 as smoke alarms were installed and
photos of the installed alarms were provided.
The issue of the child not attending school has been addressed ongoing. Teachers, the
child's therapist, the bio-mother and caregiver are active participates in obtaining a
solution to the child's unwillingness to attend school.
Safety Alert #2. The safety alert was generated on 11/06/24 as a smoke alarm was
missing between the caregivers bedroom and the rest of the home.
Resolution: Resolution weas achieved on 11/07/24 and an alarm was installed, and
photos of the alarm were submitted.
Safety Alert #3. A safety alert was generated on 11/07/24 as a smoke alarm was
missing in the basement of the home.
Resolution: Resolution was achieved on 11/08/24 as an alarm was installed and
photos provided.
Safety Alert #4. A safety alert was generated on 11/07/24 as a foster youth was
sleeping on a mattress on the floor. Bedroom doors were missing from two bedrooms
one of which was the door to the youth's bedroom.
Resolution: Resolution was achieved on 11/12/24. Youth was sleeping on bedroom
floor as advised by the youth's CMH worker as youth had been hiding alcohol and
vapes in the bed. Bedroom doors were also removed due to the alcohol and vaping
issues. A special investigation was generated by the agency on 11/08/24 to address the
issues of concern. A variance to permit the mattress on the floor and missing bedroom
doors was submitted.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
6

Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
